awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Scalable Sensor Infrastructure for Sustainably Managing the Built Environment
awd_abstract_narration:
U.S. economic growth, energy security, and environmental stewardship depend on a sustainable energy policy that promotes conservation,efficiency, and electrification across all major sectors. Buildings are the largest sector and therefore an attractive target of these efforts: current Federal sustainability goals mandate that 50% of U.S.commercial buildings become net-zero energy by 2050. A range of options exists to achieve this goal, but financial concerns require a data-driven, empirically-validated approach. However, critical gaps exist in the energy and water measurement technology, and indoorclimate control science, needed to benchmark competing options, prioritize efficiency investments, and ensure occupant comfort.

To address these challenges, this project proposes a new kind of "peel-and-stick" sensor that can be affixed to everyday objects to infer their contributions to whole-building resource consumption. To use the sensors, occupants or building managers simply tag end loads like a ceiling light, shower head, or range top. The sensors monitor the ambient conditions around a load and, using statistical methods,correlate those conditions with readings from existing electricity, gas, or water meters, providing individual estimates without intrusive metering. The sensors are built from integrated circuit technology laminated into smart labels, so they are small, inexpensive, and easy-to-deploy. The sensors are powered by the same ambient signals they sense, eliminating the need for periodic battery replacement or wall power. Collectively, these properties address cost and coverage challenges, and enable scalable deployment and widespread adoption.

The intellectual merit of this proposal stems from the insight that the transfer and use of energy (and other resources) usually emits energy, often in a different domain, and that this emitted energy is often enough to intermittently power simple, energy-harvesting sensors whose duty cycle is proportional to the energy being transferred or used. Hence, the mere activation rate of the sensors signalsthe underlying energy use. The power-proportional relationship between usage activity and side channel harvesting, when coupled with state-of-the art, millimeter-scale, nano-power chips and whole-house or panel-level meters, enables small and inexpensive sensor tags that are pervasively distributed with unbounded lifetimes. But, networking and tasking them, and making sense of their data, requires a fundamental rethinking of low-power communications, control, and data fusion to abstract the intermittent, unreliable, and noisy sensor infrastructure into actionable information.

This project's broader impact stems from an integrated program of education, research, and outreach that (i) creates a smart objects focused curriculum whose classroom projects are motivated by research needs, (ii) provides research experiences for undergraduates and
underrepresented minorities, (iii) mentors students on all aspects of successful research from articulating hypotheses to peer-reviewing papers,(iv) disseminates teaching materials on embedded systems and research pedagogy, (v) produces students who bridge disciplines,operating at the intersection of measurement science, information technology, and sustainability policy, and (vi) translates scientific discovery and technical knowledge into beneficial commercial products through industry outreach and internships, and (vii) engages with the National Labs to ensure that the research addresses pressing problems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA, THE

por.por_cntn:
Federal sustainability targets mandate that 50% of U.S. commercial buildings become net-zero energy by 2050. A growing number of states and municipalities have also adopted similar sustainability targets. A range of options exists to achieve these goals, but economic concerns require a measured and controlled approach?both figuratively and literally. Unfortunately, critical gaps exist in the measurement technology needed to efficiently benchmark building operations, identify opportunities for improvement, and monitor and verify interventions to improve performance. Lacking visibility, efforts to improve efficiency in the residential, commercial, and industrial sectors is progressing more slowly than needed to achieve our ambitious sustainability goals. However, smart and wirelessly connected sensors can give us the superpowers needed to perceive beyond our immediate senses, providing crucial visibility. While such sensors provide insights into the operations of the built environment, their installation, networking, and power provisioning have posed major barriers to widespread adoption.

In this CAREER project, we researched, developed, and demonstrated new classes of wireless sensors that address these challenges. To lower the barriers to installation, we demonstrate sensors that can be directly affixed to the objects they monitor?peel-and-stick or pin-on sensors attached to everyday things to monitor their activity or location, clip-on energy meters around electrical wires to monitor power flow, and magnetically-attached sensors to lighting and equipment that sense their operating modes?along with methods to quickly and securely commission and interact with them. To reduce the barriers to networking, we demonstrate a range of wireless communications techniques from low-power wide-area networks to short-range advertising networks to wireless backscatter networks. Finally, to address the power problems, we demonstrate how energy-harvesting power supplies that scavenge from heat, light, or magnetic fields, when coupled with a variety of energy storage options including (super)capacitors and rechargeable and non-rechargeable batteries and unconventional power management circuits, enable self-powered sensors that can operate with unbounded lifetimes.  These developments yield new capabilities, but also new challenges?like how to program embedded systems across frequent power loss.

This project also pioneered a novel and transformative energy-harvesting metering architecture. The key insight underlying these innovations, an idea we call "the Monjolo principle," is that the transfer and use of energy usually emits energy, often in a different energy domain, and that this emitted energy is often enough to intermittently power simple, energy-harvesting sensors whose duty cycle is proportional to the energy being transferred or used.  Hence, the mere activation rate of the sensors signals the underlying primary energy use or flow. The proportional relationship between primary activity and secondary energy emission or transfer, when coupled with state-of-the art, millimeter-scale, nano-power chips and whole-house or panel-level meters, enables small and inexpensive sensor tags that can be pervasively distributed with indefinite lifetimes.

Beyond typical scientific dissemination methods like papers, talks, data sets, and open-source designs, the ideas proposed, pioneered, or prototyped in this project have led to numerous broader impacts. The clip-on, energy-harvesting energy meters pioneered in this project have led to a new commercial product category called wireless current transformers (or "wireless CTs") now served by multiple firms including ones seeded or launched with subsequent NSF I-Corps support. The plug-through plug-load energy meters pioneered in this project are still the smallest and thinnest in the product category now known as "smart sockets/outlets" and they serve as the foundational technology for a DOE effort to characterize miscellaneous plug loads at scale. The peel-and-stick sensors prototyped in the project are now an emerging product category served by both niche players offering wireless temperature "stickers" for cold chain monitoring and well-funded new entrants offering wireless sensory "pixels" for monitoring products in the supply chain. A key outcome of this project is MBus, a nano-power, USB-like interconnect technology enabling modular, mm-scale sensor systems. The project?s major artifacts are open source, enabling third parties to readily use, improve, and extend the research artifacts.  Collectively, this project has yielded scalable sensor infrastructure that forms the measurement-driven foundations needed for the intelligent, efficient, and responsive buildings and supply chains of the future. And it has done so while training students to bring these new ideas to market in the form of innovative products that address pressing societal needs.


Last Modified: 07/26/2022
Modified by: Prabal Dutta

Images (1 of )
  • Monjolo, Gemini, and Triumvi wireless CTs. This figure shows the evolution of our clip-on energy-harvesting energy meters.
    Prabal Dutta
    Copyrighted
    Prabal Dutta
    Monjolo, Gemini, and Triumvi wireless CTs.
  • Shows PowerBlade, the smallest and thinnest AC plug-through plug-load meter and data visualization on a smart phone using Summon, a browser for the Web of Things.
    Prabal Dutta
    Copyrighted
    Prabal Dutta
    PowerBlade data visualization with Summon.
  • Adopted in dozens of custom integrated circuits in both academia and industry, MBus is a nano-power, USB-like interconnect technology enabling modular, mm-scale sensor systems.
    Prabal Dutta
    Copyrighted
    Prabal Dutta
    MBus interconnect and Smart Dust ecosystem.
  • A modular system of energy harvesters, processors, radio, memory and time and triggers can be combined to create a variety of energy-harvesting sensor systems for applications in building monitoring.
    Prabal Dutta
    Copyrighted
    Prabal Dutta
    Energy-harvesting sensor ecosystem.
  • The Deltaflow algorithm combines whole building power data with pulse streams from Monjolo sensors to identify and disaggregate various electrical loads.
    Prabal Dutta
    Copyrighted
    Prabal Dutta
    Deltaflow ingesting multi-modal sensor data.
  • In contrast to conventional IoT interactions with native smartphone apps, Physical Web, or web Bluetooth, Summon enabled seamless connectivity and interactivity with ambient devices and additionally supports aggregation, orchestration, data muling, and proximal actions.
    Thomas Zachariah
    Copyrighted
    Prabal Dutta
    Summon enables the Web of Things.
